src.spider_web module

class src.spider_web.SpiderWeb(max_element_per_level: int = 6)[source]

Bases: object

SpiderWeb is a custom data structure designed to organize elements in a hierarchical and indexed manner. It is implemented as a linked structure with nodes organized in levels and indices. The class provides methods for adding, querying, and removing elements based on their levels and indices within the SpiderWeb.

Example Usage:
>>> spider_web = SpiderWeb()
>>> spider_web.add(1)
>>> spider_web.add(2)
>>> spider_web.add(3)
>>> spider_web.print()
Attributes:

  • max_element_per_level: The maximum number of elements allowed per level (6).

Adds the specified element to the end of the SpiderWeb.

Parameters:

value (Any) – The value to be added to the end of the SpiderWeb.

Returns:

None

Raises:

get_maximum_index_for_level(level: int) → int[source]

Gets the maximum index for a specified level in the SpiderWeb.

Parameters:

level (int) – The level for which to retrieve the maximum index.

Returns:

The maximum index for the specified level.

Return type:

int

Raises:

  • ValueError – If the specified level is negative or exceeds the maximum level in the SpiderWeb.

  • ValueError – If the SpiderWeb is empty, and the maximum index cannot be determined.

Return type:

print() → None[source]

Prints the elements of the SpiderWeb along with their levels and indices. This method prints the elements stored in the SpiderWeb, displaying their levels and indices within the structure.

Returns:

None

size() → int[source]

Returns the size of the SpiderWeb, indicating the total number of elements stored.

Returns:

The size of the SpiderWeb.

Return type:

class src.spider_web.SpiderWebNode(value: Any, prev_node: SpiderWebNode | None = None, prev_level_node: SpiderWebNode | None = None)[source]

Bases: object

The SpiderWebNode class represents a node in the SpiderWeb data structure, where each node stores a value and maintains references to its next and previous nodes, as well as references to nodes on the next and previous levels.

Example Usage:
>>> node = SpiderWebNode(53, None, None)
Attributes:

  • value: The value stored in the node.

  • prev_node: Reference to the previous node.

  • prev_level_node: Reference to the node on the previous level.
